instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-01700: What is 820-01700? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PP2V5_NAND_SSD0: What is PP2V5_NAND_SSD0? PP2V5_NAND_SSD0 This is a power rail that powers the NAND on Macbooks where the solid state drive is soldered directly to the board. .
definitions.U8900: What is U8900? This chip creates the GPU power rails on the 820-3332 board to the 2012 and early 2013 15‚Äù Retina Macbook Pros. It becomes desoldered and is the cause of no video and kernel panics/crashes in that model most of the time..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U9400</CHIP>
threads.message:
Hello everyone

I actually read on the forum that is possible to fix ssd shorted on the line <SIGNAL>PP2V5_NAND_SSD0</SIGNAL>. I had quite an high number of SSD short with no repair. mostly of them 15inch board o 16 inch board from 2017 - 2019.

So my question is if there is a solutions to this and is possible to succeed on them. And if it applies to all the board with ssd on board.

Thanks in advance

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-01700</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> <CHIP>U9400</CHIP>
threads.message:
Yes is possible; many videos available on Internet.

You must solder the NANDs in correct order, this is very important.
For example, once you've removed <CHIP>U8600</CHIP> chip from donor board, must solder it in the same <CHIP>U8600</CHIP> place on the target board.
This is valid for swapping from exact same model board.

For 01700 need to pay atention, if you want to use NANDs from different donor model, as 00850 for example.
If both machines had 512GB, 01700 has only 5 chips mounted; <CHIP>U8600</CHIP> and <CHIP>U9100</CHIP>-400.
In such case, place the 00850 chips in ascending order (on 01700 board), starting with <CHIP>U9100</CHIP>; (00850)<CHIP>U8600</CHIP>-> <CHIP>U9100</CHIP>(01700)... (00850)<CHIP>U8900</CHIP>-><CHIP>U9400</CHIP>(01700).
Then remove the NANDs from left side SSD (<CHIP>U8600</CHIP>-900) and their power supplies.

You can play with SSD capacity in some limits.
For example 256GB, to 512GBB (standard version), changing all the chips accordingly.
But the boards with 1-8TB SSD have special T2, customized.
You can change between 1 to 8TB, but not from 512GB to 2TB for example (requires T2 changing too).

After NANDs changed, machine should automatically start in Recovery mode; detected in AC2, without pressing any key for DFU.
If not, something went wrong in the process.
